I still think those who support our 'war on terrorism' are victims of repetitious government propaganda. There are few, if any, government press releases or speeches where Iraq isn't carefully folded into the text in a manner that, despite Bush and Blair's denial of links between Iraq and al Qaeda, associates Iraq with all Islamic extremists.
 
 As a political rallying strategy, the invasion and failed occupation of Iraq has worn thin with the US Public. Even after WMDs, Saddam's iron fist governing methodology and currently foreign fighters were exhausted as rationalizations for that blunder, the new political direction is to paint all Islamic extremists with the same broad brush. When was the last time anyone heard the tired rhetoric about democracy turning Iraq and then the rest of the ME into an idealistic utopia? 
 
 We're still in the same foreign policy position as we were when 9/11 occurred. Our 'fighting' of terrorists has not changed one iota. We have this vastly expensive and growing bureaucracy called Homeland Security to combat retaliation to our foreign policy, which has less chance of stopping dedicated terrorist attacks than the French Maginot line did in deterring WW11 German flanking actions. Our national guard, normally deployed to provide security within our country, is very busy elsewhere. 
 
 The glowing publicity about our intelligence services using computer technology to cripple al Qaeda's financial base is another load of **** in the attempt to sooth the public. Anyone remotely familiar with the ME (and much of Asia) is aware that discretionary funds in that part of the world are transferred by families who have taken centuries to establish their reputations of delivering funds with no questions asked and complete secrecy. 
 
 We're running in circles and back to the starting point, again. We have added the Iraq mess to our plate, but our aggressive special interest foreign policy that demands retaliation from affected parties has not changed, nor our inability to combat dedicated, non-conventional attacks by those parties.
 
 Short of fielding a force the size of our WW11 military to invade and occupy all Islamic nations with a troop ratio ensuring total dominance, which would turn our currency into confetti, we're in a lose/lose situation. This is a long-term war of economics and we simply don't have the resources to win it without rapidly hastening the decline of our nation. A shell game and we're the greedy sucker.
